In reply to your request of April 21 for summary information
re: University of Nebraska Press and the Smather Bill, let me
forward the following:
The University of Nebraska does maintain a University
of Nebraska Press. This publication facility is under
the supervision of the Board of University Publications.
It publishes scholarly books on virtually any subject,
but special emphasis is given to manuscripts of primary
interest to this region. All manuscripts are approved
by the Board of University Publications. The Press has
national marketing facilities and in most instances wntes
standard royalty contracts.
The Press also publishes such items as "University of
Nebraska Studies"--monographs approved by the Senate
Committee on Publication of University Studies and the
Board of University Publications. The "University of
Nebraska Publications" monograms and the general areas
are journalism, education, business research, and occas¬
ionally general service publications useful to the Uni¬
versity and the state. Manuscripts are approved by the
sponsoring agencies and the Board of University Publica¬
tions. "The Prairie Schooner", a quarterly magazine of
general interest dealing with articles, short stories,
and poetry, etc.
It appears then that we are In the same position as Garrison
finds himself at the University of Michigan. The Smather Bill,
if enacted, would prohibit the University of Nebraska Press from
such publications or the University would have to give up its
television station—unless some provision is made in the bill.
